Hi,

You can have a look at J2EEUnit, which is a framework for unit 
testing server-side java code. It doesn't use 'fake' server objects 
as it runs your tests in the server's engine.

http://j2eeunit.sourceforge.net

Thanks.
Vincent.

--- In junit@y..., Magnus Rydin <magnus.rydin@c...> wrote:
> Dear sirs,
> im trying to find out the best generic way of JUnit testing J2ee
> applications.
> That would mean testing EJBs, Servlets and JSP pages, as well as 
all the
> 'normal' beans and helper classes.
> Although I've found some guidelines to how such testing could be 
performed,
> a lot of these promotes the usage of custom made 'fake' application 
servers
> and Request/Response wrappers for the Servlet testing. This feels 
extremely
> heavy..
> Is there a recommended approach that someone had good results with?
> Im thinking in the lines of having all the test cases in a separate 
WAR or
> EAR, and maybee incorporate log4j to simplify the testing.
> 
> But using printing to log4j as a result source would give the 
production
> code a unwanted overhead as well as be a very ugly way of conduct.
> 
> Please, if you've got a good design for JUnit testing in the J2EE
> environment, share it with me.
> 
> WR
subject: Re: Testing J2EE applications
